Rusty and Audrey are looking out their windows. Clark clears his throat and half-closes his eyes. He finishes with a deep, majestic voice. son, RUSTY, are in the backseat.

dialogues.text: Oh, co-o-o-me ye to Be-e-ethlehem. A-moment of reverent silence.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: . Don't worry about it, honey. Clark returns his eyes to the road, hits his signal and pulls out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family's silent with shock. Clark's in a full sweat as he struggles to maintain the exact speed of the truck to avoid being caught in the rear wheels.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: We're alright! ‘Thank God, we're alright!

dialogues.speaker: CLARK

dialogues.text: O The truck barrels along with the Taurus beneath it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Forgive us our sins...

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Just keep praying!

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.text: (to Audrey) Isn't that the kid who got picked up for sacrificing June bugs in the cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Our Lady of Jesus, we're about to get crushed by a truck!! . \ Clark takes a deep breath, clutches the wheel tightly a (> jerks it sharply to the right. cy

dialogues.text: Peace and tranquility. A virgin snowfield. a long beat and the Taurus bursts out of snowbank INTO CAMERA. Oo 45 EXT. ROAD 45 The Taurus returns to the road, crossing the left lane, then the right and off the road.

dialogues.text: A large, permanent wood sign festooned with colored lights reads -- JOLLY JERRY'S SAW 'N' SAVE CHRISTMAS TREE RANCH. The Taurus blasts past the sign and into a make-shift parking lot, sliding sideways into a parking space.

dialogues.text: Families stumble across the frozen earth between the rows of fir trees, shivering, cursing, grousing. We FIND \ Clark, Ellen, Audrey and Rusty trudging through the sno ; Co The family has a very hard go of the deep snow. Clar i pays it no mind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: They invented them, Russ, because people forgot how to have a fun, old-fashioned family Christmas and are satisfied with scrawny, dead, over-priced trees that have no special meaning. You know, kids. This is what our forefathers did.

It's a pine cylinder, eight feet in diameter. Clark looks at Ellen, Audrey and Rusty. He says nothing. They say nothing.

dialogues.text: It's pleasant and calm. A nearly perfect holiday picture. Clark's wearing a cashmere V-neck. He's un- tangling a strand of lights. Audrey, Rusty and Ellen are sitting with bowls of popcorn and cranberries in their laps. Clark has trimmed the Christmas tree branches and denuded the top twelve inches to accommodate the star. He's fishing lights out of a cardboard box.

dialogues.text: I can't get my needle through the cranberries.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY

dialogues.speaker: CLARK

dialogues.text: % He Oe

dialogues.text: You know, kids, years ago, people couldn't go out and buy their ornaments. They had to make them from things around the old prairie homestead. Colored balls of mud, wood shavings, bits of yarn and string, ox horns, donkey tails, prairie dog whiskers. I'll get the lights up and then I'll give you a hand. Clark begins stringing the lights on the tree, starting at the bottom. Clark moves slowly around the tree, stringing the lights as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: RUSTY
dialogues.text: Dad? This tradition stuff is pretty cool so far but I think it might lose its charm if it extended to our gifts. I mean, you're not planning on making our presents are you? He loads the popcorn into his mouth.

dialogues.text: Clark considers the question for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Sounds like fun... (pause) But, no.

dialogues.text: I talked to her today. They changed their mind. My dad couldn't get a good enough deal on the condo in Florida so they're coming.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Damn. (corrects himself) Darn. (again) Great! Clark pulls a large wad of sticky pine needles off the cuff of his sweater and tries to flick it into the wastebasket.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark climbs up the creaky stairs into the attic, rubbing his aching forehead. It's a standard, cluttered, wood floor, unfinished, unheated attic. He steps carefully over and around the detritus of twenty years of married life to the chimney. He sets down the bag of gifts. He takes out a gift and hides it behind the chimney. As he reaches behind the chimney, he notices something. He brings out a dusty, gift-wrapped package. He reaches back around, stretches, grits his teeth as he reaches far behind the chimney. He pulls out another wrapped gift. He sets it down and again reaches behind the chimney. He finds another gift- wrapped package. He looks at the gifts curiously. He blows the dust off one of the packages and reads the tag.

dialogues.speaker: GIFT TAG
dialogues.text: The tag reads -- TO MOM, FROM CLARK. MERRY CHRISTMAS.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He looks at another package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Todd has the cheese, fruit, wine bottle, vase and flowers on the table and is carrying it out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Get a towel! Quick! There's wine all over the carpet! Margo takes off for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen sees nothing wrong. She heads back to the door, * reaching for the light switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights go out. Margo rams into an armoire. 0.S., Todd takes a header down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art and Clark Sr. come out on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: What's all the yelling about?!

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Bewildered. He wiggles the cords furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen comes back in the house. She stops as something occurs to her. She thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art, Clark Sr., Audrey, Francis and Nora are gathered on the porch looking at Clark.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: What's he doing, Clark? CLARK SR. I haven't the foggiest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark's twisting, shaking, whipping the cords and cursing. He throws the cords down and in his rage socks * the Santa.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA
dialogues.text: The face caves in when Clark slugs it. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark kicks the reindeer and the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen turns and runs back to the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is disturbed by Clark's behavior. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He rips the cords from the junction, spreads his arms wide and with a great, dramatic gesture rams them back together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen comes back into the garage. She hits the lights. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are back on, the room is blown out with light. The armoire is toppled. A television and com- ponent stereo is spilled on the bed in a tangle of wires and video cassettes, audio cassettes and CDs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheese, fruit, flowers, wine, the table and Todd are littered down the staircase. The harsh light is spilling through the living room, dining room and’ foyer windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are on. For good.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He's stunned that the lights work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family comes down off the porch and onto the lawn, admiring the lights.

dialogues.speaker: RUSTY
dialogues.text: Wow! Dad, it's incredible! Ellen comes out of the house and runs to Clark. He takes her under his arm. Rusty under the other. Audrey hugs him and they look up at the house with great pride. The family gathers around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great swell of holiday MUSIC as we HOLD ON the magnificently-decorated house.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 129
dialogues.text: He's in tears. The struggle, the frustration, the anger has paid off. The emotion is too much for him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great moment of family warmth and love. Clark embraces Nora, then Clark Sr.

dialogues.speaker: NORA
dialogues.text: It's lovely, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: You deserve a house like this to Spend Christmas in. CLARK SR. It's a beaut, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Dad, Dad, Dad. You taught me everything I know about exterior electrical illumination. He embraces Francis.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Dear, dear Francis. I hope this adds to your enjoyment of the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: It's wonderful, Clark. Clark embraces Art.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Art, Arthur, Dad. Thanks for being here.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: You got. too many blue lights. Clark doesn't mind the insult. He regards it as a charming moment of truth and honesty.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: I know, Art. And thanks for noticing. Clark moves from Art to the next person. It's COUSIN EDDIE. He’s dressed in a cheap overcoat with a fake collar and a Kansas City Chiefs stocking cap.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The house looks real swell, Clark. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Thanks, Eddie. I hope it enhances your holiday spirit. CATHERINE'S standing next to Clark. She's wearing a quilted car coat. Clark takes her in his arms, hugs her. ©

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Catherine! Dear... Something's suddenly not right. Clark lets go of Catherine. He steps back and looks at Eddie and her. CLARK. Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: The house is gorgeous, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I sure hope you didn't do all this on our behalf, Clark. He turns and yells over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You kids get out here and see what Uncle Clark has done to the house!

dialogues.speaker: . CLARK
dialogues.text: Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He's baffled.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (to himself) Eddie? He looks off and is hit with another surprise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The biggest commercially-available RV is backed in his driveway. The door opens and two little kids, a boy and a girl, ROCKY and RUBY SUE, followed by a mixed breed hound, Snots, jump out. Rocky's six and Ruby Sue's five. The kids and dog run across the lawn (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He's stunned. He looks at Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: She's equally stunned. She shrugs. She doesn't have any idea why Eddie and Catherine have shown up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Catherine greet the grandparents as the kids walk up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: If you don't remember, this is Rocky.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: You got a kiss for me?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Better take a raincheck on that, Art. He's got a lip fungus they ain't identified yet. Art pats Rocky on the head.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You remember Ruby Sue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Oh, my gosh! Her eyes aren't crossed anymore!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Somethin', ain't it? Falls in a well, eyes go crossed. Gets kicked by a mule, they go back to normal. Eddie slaps Snots on the flanks.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: This here is our pride and joy. Snots.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Pretty name, Ed. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We named him that 'cause he's got sinus troubles.

dialogues.speaker: SNOTS
dialogues.text: He SNIFFS, CLEARS his THROAT and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... SPITS. Clark looks up with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (to Snots) Snots, you roll over and let Uncle Clark scratch your belly. (to Clark) You never saw a set on a dog like this one's got.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: It's alright, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You rub his belly, Clark, and he'll love you till the day you die.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: I really shouldn't. My hands are chapped.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (to Ellen) We would have called, but Eddie _wanted to make it a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Clark? You surprised?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Surprised? Eddie, if I woke tomorrow with my head sewed to the carpet, I couldn't be more surprised than I am right now. Ellen gives Clark an angry look.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We have plenty of room. Plenty of everything. (to herself) I think. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We're pretty much set in the R.V. It's a little tight, but we didn't come to impose.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: Hell, there's plenty of room. (to Eddie) Quit being so damn polite, Ed. You want to spend the holidays with four people jammed toe-to- nose in a motor home? Eddie reevaluates his position.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Catherine and me are comfy in there. Maybe you folks wouldn't mind the youngsters shacking up with you. After that drive... (puts his arm around Catherine) We could use some time together. (to Catherine) Honey, run and get the kids' things. And don't forget the rubber sheets and the gerbils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark and Eddie are standing at the tree sipping eggnog. Eddie's wearing a flannel shirt tucked into sweat pants and leather tie shoes. He's showered. His hair's combed back.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Honey of a tree, Clark. Is it a real one?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Dug it out of the ground myself.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Is that a fact...? Clark reaches under the tree.

dialogues.speaker: SNOTS
dialogues.text: He's drinking the water out of the tree stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark shoos the dog out from under the tree. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Get outta there!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, Clark, a little tree water ain't gonna hurt him. Before we left, he drank half a quart of Pennzoil. Boy, when he lifted his leg the next morning...

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: If he drinks the water out of there, the tree'll dry out.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Snots! Get outta there! Go to the kitchen and get something to eat! The dog saunters out of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Cute, isn't he? Only problem is, he's got a little Mississippi leg hound in him. If the mood catches him right, he'll grab your leg and go to town. You don't want him around if you're wearing short pants, if you know what I mean. A word of warning, though. If he does start on you, you best let him finish.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (changes the subject) I just can't believe you're actually standing here in my living room. I never thought the day would come.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I'm excited about it, too. It's a cryin' shame the older kids couldn't make it. I got the daughter in the clinic to get cured off the Wild Turkey and the older boy, bless his soul, is preparing for his career.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: College?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Carnival. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (facetiously) You gotta be proud.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. He worked last season as a pixie dust spreader on the Tilt-O-Whirl and he thinks maybe next season he'll be guessing people's weight or barking for the Yak Woman. You ever see her?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Sorry to say I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Big horns growing right above her ears. Ugly as sin but a real sweet gal and a hell of a good cook.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (changing the subject ) Can I refill your eggnog, get you something to eat, drive you out to the middle of nowhere and leave you for dead? Eddie doesn't catch the insult. There's a

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I'm doing fine, Clark. Just glad to be here. lull in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. So, when did you get the tenement on wheels?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That's an R.V. I borrowed it off my buddy. He took my house. We took the R.V. It's a good-lookin' vehicle, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Beautiful. And it looks so nice backed in the driveway. .

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Sure does, but don't go fallin' in love with it. When we leave next month, it's goin' with us. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: A134
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.text: The house is glowing. Neighbors have gathered in the street and on the adjacent lawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From several blocks away, the house continues to glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark's house glows in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: He's staring at the ceiling. He's bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: Two big foot holes are punched through the bimbo's chest.

dialogues.speaker: ART
dialogues.text: He gives up trying to figure out what happened to the poster. He rolls over and settles into the bed. He turns AWAY FROM CAMERA revealing that the back of his head is white with plaster dust. As he pulls the covers up around his shoulders, a cloud of dust rises.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY AND RUBY SUE B134
dialogues.text: They're sleeping in the hide-a-bed. A cage packed with anxious gerbils rests between them. Rocky smiles and we hear the SOFT SPLATTER of WATER on rubber. We MOVE OFF them TO the floor and Rusty and Audrey. Rusty's laying on top of Audrey. She's struggling beneath his dead-weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark and Ellen are in bed, awake. The lights are off. The room is illuminated by the outdoor lights.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: I'm not complaining, I just don't know how we can have a nice Christmas with Eddie here.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Well, they are sleeping the driveway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: And isn't that a kick in the nuts? How can the house look like anything but a junkyard with his shack on wheels parked in the driveway?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You've never judged anyone by how much or how little they have, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: No, and I never will. If Eddie was rich... There's a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK / ELLEN
dialogues.text: He's be worse.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Good night, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTMAS CALENDAR 134
dialogues.text: Eddie's greasy fingers tear off a door marked, DEC. 21, to reveal a sprig of mistletoe. He leaves a big smudge mark on the calendar.

dialogues.speaker: SANTA
dialogues.text: MOVE UP FROM Santa's crushed face TO the house and the RV The door opens and Eddie lets Snots out. Snots sniffs out the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-morning in the business district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark pokes his head inside. No secretary. He tiptoes in, holding a poinsettia plant. He crosses to a door, knocks twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast room with an enormous desk. Shirley is seated behind it, having a conversation over the speaker phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Get Ed Leftic up here and have him look over these figures. Clark enters with the poinsettia.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Mr. Shirley, merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SHIRLEY 139
dialogues.text: He's become Scrooge counting his money. He doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 140
dialogues.text: edging forward.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: It's me, Clark Griswold. I have a gift for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Shirley is back to normal. He waves toward an opposite wall.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Put it over there with the others, Grisball.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: (can't resist) By the way, sir. Hope my report helped out at the trade show.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I'm sure it did. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm in the middle of an important call. He picks up the receiver. Clark turns to put the poinsettia on a sideboard and sees it's jammed with about fifty other poinsettias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taurus rolls through heavily-wooded, snow-covered hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big wooden sign that reads ~- OSHGONOGGIN STATE PARK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parking lot at the bottom. A warming house. Outdoor light illuminates the hill. CHRISTMAS CAROLS are playing on the PA,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark, Eddie, Audrey, Rusty, Ruby Sue and Rocky are at th top of a suburban park sledding hill. They each have a saucer sled. Clark's on one knee with his saucer sled upside-down on the snow. He's shaking a spray can.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: This is a new non-caloric silicon- based kitchen lubricant my company's working on. It creates a surface 500 times slipperier than any cooking oil. We're really gonna fly down the hill with this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: RUSTY
dialogues.text: Has anybody ever put it on a sled?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Not that I know of.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Don't put none of it on my sled, Clark. You know that metal plate in my head?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: How could I forget it? He sprays the bottom of the sled.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I had to have it replaced because whenever Catherine revved-up the microwave I'd piss my pants and forget who I was for half hour or so. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Over at V.A. they replaced it with a plastic one and it ain't as strong. I don't think I oughta be sailing down no hill with nothing between the ground and my brain but a piece of government plastic. Clark's growing weary of the endless blabbering.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Do you really think it matters, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The plate runs right under my part. If it gets dented, my hair ain't gonna look right. Clark groans and flips his sled right-side up.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Let me go first and see how it works.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Be careful there, Clark.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: There's nothing to worry about, Ed. Clark mounts the sled.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Going for a new amateur recreational saucer sled land speed record, Clark W. Griswold, Jr. He sets his palms on the snow and rocks the sled back and forth. It's extremely slippery.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. This is gonna be some kind of wild ride! Clark rocks himself back, holds a split second and pushes off. The sled flies off the peak of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking straight down the hill. Clark's sled streaks down the hill, across the flat and into the dark beyond. One moment he's on top of the hill, the next, he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A146 OMITTED. Al46 *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're stunned by how fast Clark flew down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark's sled sails through the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He's holding on for dear life, screaming all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOW and MOVING. Barely missing cars, people jumping out of the way and heading for a Jeep.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He leans back and closes his eyes in anticipation of serious injury. Oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOW. The sled shoots under the Jeep and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark's sled flies out of the parking lot and onto the street. He reappears every few seconds as he passes through the pools of street lamp light. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavily wooded area. Branches are breaking, BIRDS are roused and SQUAWKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big red and green metal bin resting in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the darkness into the harsh mercury vapor light of the parking lot, comes Clark and his sled. Sparks fly as he strikes dry pavement. “ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He opens his eyes for a terrified moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The collection box is coming up fast. A freshly-painted Santa and the words HO! HO! HO! is on the red bin.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He braces for the crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, we hear the METAL BOOM of Clark's impact

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Binge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting behind his desk, staring out the window. Bill walks in.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Clark? Clark turns in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Staying late?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Just finishing up a few things. Last day of the year for me.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Have a really merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Thank you. You, too. Bill starts to exit. Clark stops him.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Did you get your bonus yet?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I just talked to my son. He said a messenger brought a company envelope to the house. I guess that's it. Nothing like waiting until the last minute. Did you get yours? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clark shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: If it's not already at your place, it has to be on its way. Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: CLAKR
dialogues.text: If I don't get my bonus I'm in it... (hand to his nose) ++. up to here.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Don't sweat it. It'll come. Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Same to you. Bill exits.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: He's concerned that something's gone wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exterior lights are on. The interior lights are off except for a single light in the kitchen. It's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark's in a red bathrobe, standing at the sink looking out the window. He's lost in troubled thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out the window. It's daytime. The pool is in and the kids are in the water.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 155
dialogues.text: A big, happy, dreamy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark and Ellen have joined the fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 157
dialogues.text: He slips deeper into his fantasy. MUSIC FADES UP.  158 159 160 161 162 163 164 165 166 167 168

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, the girl from the department store, is bouncing on the diving board. MUSIC'S PLAYING. She plays to Clark in the kitchen, waving for him to come out.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 159
dialogues.text: In the window, looking out. It's dark inside, light outside. Mary's reflected in the window glass. Clark's in his robe. He shakes his head, "no." He's embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 160
dialogues.text: Big, sexy smile. She mouths, "Come on!"

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 161
dialogues.text: From the outside. He begs off again.

dialogues.speaker: MARY 162
dialogues.text: She reaches around behind her back and (BELOW FRAME) unfastens her top.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 163
dialogues.text: He presses his face to the cold glass.

dialogues.speaker: MARY'S FEET 164
dialogues.text: She kicks off her bathing suit bottom.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 165
dialogues.text: His face is severely pressed to the window. The bathing suit bottom hits the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby Sue appears in the doorway, in her pajamas, rubbing sleepy eyes. She squints. She sees Clark. Her jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark is leaning against the sink with his face pressed to the window. We hear a SPLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary surfaces and swims to the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK 168
dialogues.text: He's straining for a better view.  qd.

dialogues.text: She begins to rise from the water and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are wide and her jaw is slack.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: Holy shit! Santa Claus!

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: From outside. It's dark again. The pool fantasy has evaporated. He's startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets out a sharp cry as he turns quickly from the window to face Ruby Sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruby Sue approaches Clark.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: Uncle Clark! Are you Santy Claus?

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Boy, you scared me. No. I'm not Santa Claus. I wish I was. Clark sits at the kitchen table and pats his heart. He composes himself. :

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: How come you're up, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: Rocky bit my thumb.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: My mom puts bad tasting crap on his thumb so he don't suck it so sometimes he sucks mine and he has a bad dream, sometimes he bites it.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: Him's nervous because Christmas is almost here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clark senses a problem. He sits down and offers his knee ta Ruby Sue. cb

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Excited or nervous?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: Shitting bricks.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: You shouldn't use that word.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: Sorry. He's shitting rocks.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Don't use the 'S' word.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
dialogues.text: Oh. Him's nervous because he don't know if he's getting nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CLARK
dialogues.text: Are you in school?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY SUE
